about.title: Who are we?
about.body: A multi-service welding company that provides innovative, custom solutions for a wide array of industrial, commercial, and agricultural clients.

services.title: Services
services.body: Thompson Boiler Works Inc. with our affiliated companies, Ritchie’s Welding and McNolty Mechanical, offer our customers a wide range of versatile welding procedures & metal fabricating. As a full-service welding operation where safety is our top priority, clients receive accurate results from certified welders who follow all trade regulations and practices.

projects.title: Projects
projects.body: Thompson Boiler Works is a one-stop-shop for your needs. With the ability to tackle large or small projects when complex welding or outside-the box-thinking is needed.  The team is engaged and strives daily in doing the work correctly, the first time. We have proven time and time again that we work well in time-sensitive situations to meet deadlines and satisfy the need of our customers.

one.body: Privately owned and operated since 1988. Thompson Boiler Works has come a long way from its beginnings. Originally specializing in commercial industrial boiler making and repairs, we now (over 33 years later) encompass other aspects of the commercial-industrial mechanical field while maintaining the core business of boilers and pressure vessels.

two.body: Thompson Boiler Works Inc. was built on quality and continues to deliver our high standards. Our core value is our people and our customers. We provide premier service with benchmark levels of safety, turnaround time, and cooperation. While also specializing in finding solutions to complex problems by partnering with our clients. Through teamwork, we complete your projects safely, on time, and within budget.

one.name: Eric Thompson (Retired)
one.subtitle: Founder, High Pressure welder, Gas technician, Oil Burner Mechanic, Boilermaker
one.body: The founder of Thompson Boiler Works in 1988. Working in the field as a high-pressure welder, gas and oil technician and boilermaker until his retirement in 2003, when his son Jason Thompson was appointed President of the company.

two.name: Jason Thompson
two.subtitle: President
two.body: Joining the family business in 1989, Jason started as a labourer/apprentice and eventually graduating to a high-pressure welder, pipefitter, and boilermaker. Later appointed to President of Thompson Boiler Works Inc in 2003, Jason continues to maintain the core business of boilers and pressure vessels while encompassing other aspects of the commercial, industrial, and mechanical fields. In 2017, Jason acquired the skills and experience of Ritchies Welding Inc., followed respectively by McNolty Mechanical in 2020. Jason attributes the success of the companies to his many customers, suppliers, and his loyal employees.

three.name: Martin Vinette
three.subtitle: High Pressure welder, Pipe fitter, Boilermaker
three.body: Martin has been employed with Thompson Boiler Works since 1997. He is responsible for developing customer relations, scheduling of the field welders/boiler makers, field production for all projects and troubleshooting as needed. His many years of experience working in the field as a High-Pressure Welder-Pipe Fitter-Boilermaker on both large and small projects has made the transition to Director of Operations seamless.

four.name: Dave Kollesh
four.subtitle: High Pressure welder, Pipe fitter, Boilermaker
four.body: Dave has been employed with Thompson Boiler Works since 1999. Initially hired as an experience high-pressure welder, pipe fitter, boilermaker, with over 10 years proven experience in the field as a welder. Over the last 15 years Dave’s versatility and ability to adapt to changing environments has gradually transitioned him to his present position as Office Manager/Material Buyer. He manages and oversees the day-to-day administration, accounting, payroll, material buying and customer service.

five.name: Claude Turpin
five.subtitle: Certified Journeyman Plumber, Steamfitter, Pipe fitter, and Petroleum Equipment Mechanic 2 and 3.
five.body: Claude joined Thompson Boiler Work in 2018 in the role of Senior Project Manager. He is responsible for identifying and developing new opportunities with clients, processing bid tenders and submitting proposals, coordinating team members to ensure all parties are on track with project requirements, deadlines, and schedules. He also visits job sites to ensure all project requirements are executed as identified in the drawings and specifications, meets with team members to identify and resolve issues, and co-ordinates with internal resources and suppliers for the execution of projects.

six.name: Maud Simoneau
six.body: Maud joined Thompson Boiler Works in 2018 in the role of Project Manager. Maud has been in the boiler business for many years she brings a wide range of knowledge and experience in this field. She is presently responsible for the planning, troubleshooting, and executing the detail scope of work required for each project. She meets with the project team members to identify and resolve issues. She facilitates change requests to ensure that all parties are advised of the impacts on schedule and budget. Lastly, she manages customer satisfaction within the project during the transition period and conducting post-project evaluation to ensure the success of each project.

one.title: Zibi
one.body: TBW has been part of the ZIBI development for the last 4 years. In working with the Eddy Lands Projects team (Ed Brunet and Ledcor), we have been part of the team that installed their infrastructure program for the District Thermal system. This system will provide the necessary energy requirements to the mix usage development plan with LTHW (Low Temperature Hot Water), HTHW (Hot Temperature Hot Water) and CHW (Chilled Water). These networks of pipes are being linked between Ontario and Quebec under the Union Bridge and underground through Booth St and other surrounding streets.
one.imageAlt: Zibi - Ottawa – Bridge connection from power plant to building connecting Ontario and Quebec.

two.title: Strathcona
two.body: Installation of a new saturated steam boiler 80,000 lbs/hr. the scope of work required dismantling of the old boiler, rigging new boiler inside the steam plant, installing the new boiler with all accessories which included economizer, FD fan, piping for all services, heat exchanger, controls, and electricals.
two.imageAlt: Strathcona-Ontario – Installation PRV station on steam line

three.title: Kirkland Lake
three.body: Removal and Replacement of Economizer of a Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG) at North Power Station in Kirkland Lake, the weigh of the Replacement Economizer is 80,000 lbs. For this removal and installation of the Economizer a mobile crane with counterweights (500-ton Super Max) was required. The new Economizer arrived in a horizontal position on site with a lifted bed. The procedure for lifting the Economizer from horizontal position to vertical position required two mobile cranes with a rigging procedure in place, using a 550-ton super Max crane with a 90-ton crane.
three.imageAlt: Kirkland Lake Power Plant – Removal of old Heat Exchanger

four.title: Queenway Carleton Hospital
four.body: Retubing of High Pressure Firetube Boiler used for heating and processing sanitation
four.imageAlt: Front View of 600 HP Fire Tube Boiler ready for retubing at Ottawa Hospital Facility.

five.title: Ottawa University
five.body: Installation at the University of Ottawa (Central Heating and cooling plant). All associated supply and return piping was 10,12,16” Stainless Steel piping and fiberglass. Extensive heavy lift/rigging/offsite fabrication and commissioning.
five.imageAlt: Cooling tower replacement at University of Ottawa
